xxl.core.xxlinq
Class ResettableSequentializer<E>

java.lang.Object
  xxl.core.cursors.AbstractCursor<E>
      xxl.core.xxlinq.ResettableSequentializer<E>
Type Parameters:
E - the type of the elements returned by this iteration.
All Implemented Interfaces:
java.util.Iterator<E>, Cursor<E>
public class ResettableSequentializer<E>
extends AbstractCursor<E>

A sequentializer concatenates n input iterations to a single one. To provide this functionality, it internally accesses an iteration of input iterations specified by the user and stores a reference to the currently processed inout iteration. If this input iteration has been completely consumed, the next input iteration delivered by the internal iteration of input iterations will be processed. Moreover it is possible to define a function delivering the second input input iteration to be processed.

Implementation details: The attribute cursor represents the currently processed input iteration and is set by the method hasNextObject to the next input iteration as follows: 

     while (!cursor.hasNext()) {
         cursor.close();
         if (iteratorsCursor.hasNext())
             cursor = Cursors.wrap(iteratorsCursor.next());
         else
             cursor = new EmptyCursor<E>();
     }
The method next returns the next element of the currently used input iteration, i.e., the next method of cursor is called. So a sequentializer sets the attribute cursor to the first input iteration and returns this iteration by lazy evaluation, after that the attribute cursor is set to the next input iteration and so on.

Note: When the given input iteration only implements the interface Iterator it is wrapped to a cursor by a call to the static method wrap.

Example usage (1): 

     Sequentializer<Integer> sequentializer = new Sequentializer<Integer>(
         new Enumerator(11),
         new Enumerator(11, 21)
     );
 
     sequentializer.open();
 
     while (sequentializer.hasNext())
         System.out.print(sequentializer.next() + "; ");
     System.out.flush();
     System.out.println();
 
     sequentializer.close();
This instance of a sequentializer concatenates the two given enumerators. The first enumerator contains the elements 0,...,10. The second one contains the elements 11,...,20. So the result of the completely consumed sequentializer is an ascending sequence with range [0, 20].

Example usage (2): 

     sequentializer = new Sequentializer<Integer>(
         new Enumerator(1, 4),
         new Function<Object, Cursor<Integer>>() {
             public Cursor<Integer> invoke() {
                 return new Enumerator(4, 7);
             }
         }
     );
 
     sequentializer.open();
 
     while (sequentializer.hasNext())
         System.out.print(sequentializer.next() + "; ");
 
     System.out.flush();
     System.out.println();
 
     sequentializer.close();
This instance of a sequentializer concatenates the three elements of the first enumerator (1, 2, 3) with the elements of the second enumerator delivered by invoking the defined function. So the output printed to the output stream is: 
     1; 2; 3; 4; 5; 6;

Example usage (3): 

     sequentializer = new Sequentializer<Integer>(
         new HashGrouper<Integer>(
             new Enumerator(21),
             new Function<Integer, Integer>() {
                 public Integer invoke(Integer next) {
                     return next % 5;
                 }
             }
         )
     );
 
     sequentializer.open();
 
     while (sequentializer.hasNext())
         System.out.print(sequentializer.next() + "; ");
     System.out.flush();
     System.out.println();
 
     sequentializer.close();
This example demonstrates the sequentializer's concatentation using a constructor that receives an iteration of input iterations as paramater. The used hash-grouper is a cursor and each element of this cursor points to a group of the used hash-map, realized as a cursor. The elements of the enumerator are inserted in the buckets of the hash-map by applying the given function on them. So the buckets with keys 0,...,4 remain and are filled up. For further details see HashGrouper. Now the sequentializer takes these buckets (cursors) and concatenates them. So the output is: 
     4; 9; 14; 19; 3; 8; 13; 18; 2; 7; 12; 17; 1; 6; 11; 16; 0; 5; 10; 15; 20;

See Also:
Iterator, Cursor, AbstractCursor

Field Detail

cursors

protected java.util.List<Cursor<E>> cursors
A list of all cursors to be concatenated. This allows the Sequentializer to be reset().

iteratorsCursor

protected java.util.Iterator<? extends Cursor<E>> iteratorsCursor
The iteration containing the input cursors to be sequentialized. Fetched from cursors

cursor

protected Cursor<E> cursor
The currently processed input iteration. The constructors set this cursor to a new empty cursor. This cursor is set in the method hasNextObject to the next input iteration as follows: 
     while (!cursor.hasNext()) {
         if (iteratorsCursor.hasNext())
             cursor = iteratorsCursor.next();
         else
             cursor = new EmptyCursor<E>();
     }
If the input iteration is given by an iterator it is wrapped to a cursor.

Constructor Detail

ResettableSequentializer

public ResettableSequentializer(java.util.Iterator<? extends java.util.Iterator<E>> cursorsIterator)
Creates a new sequentializer backed on a finite iteration of input iterations. Every iterator given to this constructor is wrapped to a cursor that is stored in an internal list (that's why cursorsIterator needs to be finite).

Parameters:
cursorsIterator - iteration of input iterations to be sequentialized.

ResettableSequentializer

public ResettableSequentializer(java.util.Iterator<E>... iterators)
Creates a new sequentializer backed on an array of input iterations. Every iterator given to this constructor is wrapped to a cursor.

Parameters:
iterators - an array of input iterations to be sequentialized.

ResettableSequentializer

public ResettableSequentializer(java.util.Iterator<E> iterator,
                                Function<?,? extends java.util.Iterator<E>> function)
Creates a new sequentializer backed on an input iteration and a parameterless function returning the second input iteration on demand. Every iterator given to this constructor is wrapped to a cursor.

Parameters:
iterator - the first input iteration to be sequentialized.
function - a parameterless function returning the second input iteration to be sequentialized on demand. This function is invoked after the first input iteration has been processed completely.
Method Detail

close

public void close()
Closes the sequentialier, i.e., signals it to clean up resources, close input iterations, etc. When a cursor has been closed calls to methods like next or peek are not guaranteed to yield proper results. Multiple calls to close do not have any effect, i.e., if close was called the cursor remains in the state closed.

Note, that a closed cursor usually cannot be opened again because of the fact that its state generally cannot be restored when resources are released respectively files are closed.

Specified by:
close in interface Cursor<E>
Overrides:
close in class AbstractCursor<E>

hasNextObject

protected boolean hasNextObject()
Returns true if the iteration has more elements. (In other words, returns true if next or peek would return an element rather than throwing an exception.)

The attribute cursor is set by this method to the next input iteration as follows: 

     while (!cursor.hasNext()) {
         
         if (iteratorsCursor.hasNext())
             cursor = iteratorsCursor.next();
         else
             cursor = new EmptyCursor<E>();
     }
If the next input iteration is given by an iterator it is wrapped to a cursor. The method returns whether the currently processed input iteration contains further elements, i.e., the result of the hasNext method of cursor.

Specified by:
hasNextObject in class AbstractCursor<E>
Returns:
true if the sequentializer has more elements.

nextObject

protected E nextObject()
Returns the next element in the iteration. This element will be accessible by some of the sequentializer's methods, e.g., update or remove, until a call to next or peek occurs. This is calling next or peek proceeds the iteration and therefore its previous element will not be accessible any more.

Specified by:
nextObject in class AbstractCursor<E>
Returns:
the next element in the iteration.

remove

public void remove()
            throws java.lang.IllegalStateException,
                   java.lang.UnsupportedOperationException
Removes from the underlying data structure the last element returned by the sequentializer (optional operation). This method can be called only once per call to next or peek and removes the element returned by this method. Note, that between a call to next and remove the invocation of peek or hasNext is forbidden. The behaviour of a cursor is unspecified if the underlying data structure is modified while the iteration is in progress in any way other than by calling this method.

Note, that this operation is optional and might not work for all cursors.

Specified by:
remove in interface java.util.Iterator<E>
Specified by:
remove in interface Cursor<E>
Overrides:
remove in class AbstractCursor<E>
Throws:
java.lang.IllegalStateException - if the next or peek method has not yet been called, or the remove method has already been called after the last call to the next or peek method.
java.lang.UnsupportedOperationException - if the remove operation is not supported by the sequentializer.

supportsRemove

public boolean supportsRemove()
Returns true if the remove operation is supported by the sequentializer. Otherwise it returns false.

Specified by:
supportsRemove in interface Cursor<E>
Overrides:
supportsRemove in class AbstractCursor<E>
Returns:
true if the remove operation is supported by the sequentializer, otherwise false.

update

public void update(E object)
            throws java.lang.IllegalStateException,
                   java.lang.UnsupportedOperationException
Replaces the last element returned by the sequentializer in the underlying data structure (optional operation). This method can be called only once per call to next or peek and updates the element returned by this method. Note, that between a call to next and update the invocation of peek or hasNext is forbidden. The behaviour of a cursor is unspecified if the underlying data structure is modified while the iteration is in progress in any way other than by calling this method.

Note, that this operation is optional and might not work for all cursors.

Specified by:
update in interface Cursor<E>
Overrides:
update in class AbstractCursor<E>
Parameters:
object - the object that replaces the last element returned by the sequentializer.
Throws:
java.lang.IllegalStateException - if the next or peek method has not yet been called, or the update method has already been called after the last call to the next or peek method.
java.lang.UnsupportedOperationException - if the update operation is not supported by the sequentializer.
